titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John Crean Cardwell and Grace Ann Parker correspondence 2021.002
titlestmt.author: Maggie Schreiner

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-08-25 14:07:35 +0000.

did.unittitle: John Crean Cardwell and Grace Ann Parker correspondence

physdesc.extent: in one full and one half manuscript box.

did.abstract: This collection consists of correspondence, primarily between John Crean Cardwell, a physician, and his wife Grace Ann Parker. The correspondence between John and Grace starts in 1891, when they would have both been 25 years old, and continues until 1910. For several years between 1900 and 1905, Grace lived in Switzerland, where she received treatment for tuberculosis. The letters discuss John's medical practice, details about patients and treatments, as well as daily life in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists exclusively of correspondence, primarily between John Crean Cardwell and Grace Ann Parker. The correspondence between John and Grace starts in 1891, when they were both been 25 years old, and continues until 1910. For several years between 1900 and 1905, Grace lived in Switzerland, where she received treatment for tuberculosis. The letters discuss John's medical practice, details about patients and treatments, as well as daily life in Brooklyn. There is one folder of correspondence between John Crean Cardwell and Nathan Breiler, a presumed college friend.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Crean Cardwell (July 23 1866 to August 3 1940) was born in Philadelphia, PA to George Cardwell, a store clerk, and Margaretta Richards. John attended the Bellevue Hospital Medical College, and later taught neurology and physiology at Harvard Medical School from 1891-1893, before returning to Brooklyn and becoming a practicing physician. Grace Ann Parker (March 25 1866 to February 4 1941) was born in Worcester MA to Henry Langdon Parker (1832-1910), a lawyer and Massachusetts state legislator, and Isabelle Hopewell Hayden Mason. Grace was an artist and studied at the Massachusetts Normal Art School, in Florence, Italy, and later at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn. After she graduated she was supervisor of Art in the Worcester Public Schools for two years. John and Grace were married on June 10th, 1897, in Worcester MA. Grace soon joined John in Brooklyn, where they lived until their deaths in 1940 and 1941.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically by date.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Material in this collection is in the public domain.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); John Crean Cardwell and Grace Ann Parker correspondence, 2021.002, Box and Folder number; Center for Brooklyn History, Brooklyn Public Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Anne Soukup, the granddaughter of Grace Anne Parker's nephew Dean Huntington Parker, in 2021.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of donation, letters were arranged in bundles by date. Letters were rehoused in acid free folders and boxes, and remain folded in their original envelopes.

did.unittitle: Correspondence between John Cardwell and Nathan Breiler
